questions.neutral: Is your night just starting or ending?

hobby.message: Analog photography still treating you right?
Urban exploration or just avoiding work?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Ending, I think. Not much out there for me tonight.
Just finished with some... personal work. I do analog street photography.
Film's hard to come by these days, even harder since the protests.
Seems the city prefers digital eyes over human ones.
Let’s call it a layover, not quite starting or ending.
I was out with my camera again. Only shoot on 35mm film.
Crowds made it impossible tonight. Too many patrols since the data leaks.
You’re lucky if you get a shot before getting rerouted.
The air isn’t friendly for hobbyists like me lately.
Kind of in between, honestly. Needed a break after a long walk.
I shoot old-school street photography, all analog. Smuggled film is gold now.
Was trailing the tribunal crowds—lost track of time.
Capturing the unrest these days is less about art, more about memory.
Getting film through security takes more nerve than talent now.
City’s changed—people look different when they think they’re being watched.
I’d say it’s both—rest and reset. Street photography keeps me ground-level.
Nothing digital, all 35mm analog—best way to catch people unfiltered.
Tonight I was with the newly restored ghosts downtown.
Shooting protests used to be risky, now it’s nearly a miracle.
After that last tribunal hearing, patrols tripled and access shut down.
I stash film in my boot and keep moving between crowds.
Honestly, I like how the raw tension shows up in grainy negatives.
Honestly, neither. My nights blur together when I’m chasing the truth through a lens.
I grew up around BCI officers—learned early that film tells what algorithms can’t.
My analog street shots—real, unrated, impossible for the Council to edit.
Last week, right after the tribunal, I caught a shot of a ghost returning home.
No digital trace, just pure film—dangerous and precious.
Security’s tighter. I had to hide rolls in a drainpipe after patrols passed.
Shooting now feels like defiance—every frame is a little protest.
I keep going. Someone has to save a version of the truth no system can overwrite.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still hanging onto it.
Film’s harder to get now, thanks to the city lockdowns.
Most places don’t want “ghosts” with cameras around.
People get edgy if you point a lens after the tribunal fiasco.
Guess I just keep my head down.
Still doing it, yeah.
Getting film’s a pain post-data leak; every vendor’s paranoid now.
Now everyone assumes you’re a reporter or a spy, not just curious.
Crowds act different after all the ghosts came back.
Shots are messier, but maybe that’s the point lately.
Mostly just watch and wait for the right moment.
Analog’s still my thing. Never trusted the feeds.
Tribunal days had the best light: real faces, no edits.
Used to be, people posed. Now after the leaks, everyone avoids the frame.
Film runs out fast. Vendors are spooked since the BCI crash.
Still, those ‘ghost citizens’—can’t capture that with a filter.
Had to hide a roll after someone flagged me in the square.
Guess I work faster now. Less chance to hesitate, more truth.
Wouldn’t give up my camera for anything. Even if the city’s on fire.
Since the tribunal, everything’s changed—shots mean something again.
Ghosts blend in, but you see who’s watching whom if you look sharp.
Film’s nearly impossible to score. I barter, hide it, reload in alleys now.
Used to show colleagues; now they delete all traces if I mention it.
BCI dropped me to the bottom; people step aside or vanish when I lift the lens.
But the moments I get now—just raw, unfiltered. History, not propaganda.
Sometimes I think being erased lets you see the city for the first time.
Yeah, analog’s my only truth left. Dad used to say a photo can indict a system.
I shoot more since the leaks, even though half my old haunts ghosted me.
Bar 101’s still safe-ish, but patrols tail me after the last broadcast.
I slipped into the tribunal crowd, loaded with expired Fuji, snapping faces you’ll never see on state TV.
Film’s tough—vendors got blacklisted, and if you’re flagged, they pretend you don’t exist.
Used to develop at home in secret. Now, even my fixer’s hiding—says too many eyes are hunting for evidence, for ghosts.
Every shot now feels urgent, proof against their revision.
Being marked ‘8’ means people flinch if I click, but I see more—isolation sharpens the view.
In a way, being outside the grid just confirmed I was right to trust film over feeds.
